There are three main things that contribute to the idea that trolls/griefers/inters don't get punished. I'll preface this by saying, I assure you they do.
___
**.1. The difference between feeding and intentional feeding.**

Even when you are in the game with someone, it can be difficult from a player perspective to determine whether someone is feeding because they're tilted (which is, unfortunately, a big ol' snowball effect) and someone who is feeding because they decided to be an asshole for whatever reason.

Riot have a lot more background info and data that goes into determining what's an intentional pattern, what's a tilt pattern, what's a "my lane is just better than me" pattern, etc, etc.

That's not to say that inters don't exist, because they obviously do, but there is more consideration to a punishment than simply how many deaths someone has.
___
**.2. Trolling/Griefing vs Disagreeing.**

League is incredibly diverse, and no game plays out the same way. There is no one *right* way to play League, and in any given game there are multiple routes to victory. So is someone ignoring your Baron call because they're griefing and want to mess with you, or are they ignoring it because they disagree with the call and think it will get you all killed?

Unfortunately, human nature dictates that we don't like admitting we are or could be wrong about things, or that someone could be more right. Someone ignoring your advice, no matter how logical or sound you think it is, doesn't mean they are griefing you or intentionally trolling. More often than not, it's simply that they disagree with your decision.

Tilt exacerbates this badly. If someone has dismissed your calls as meaningless they will ignore them regardless of how sound the logic is behind them.

Those that have a solo mindset and fall into this trap all the time, are going to be at a severe disadvantage when it comes to ranked (teamwork is an important skill too after all) so try not to worry about them too much. Rank is after all, largely about the big picture and not the game to game.

One thing you can do to mitigate this is to understand that following through on a questionable call as a team, is still generally going to be the better option than following through on 5 different calls that alone, or leaving your team to 4v5/3v5 while you go off on your own. Wards help a lot here too.
___
**.3. How to determine intent.**

This very much ties into the first two points, but it is essentially the largest hurdle any system faces when issuing punishments for gameplay offences.

Chat is fairly simple. The expression of intent is right there in plain old recorded English (or [insert other language here]). There are still borderline or questionable instances, but for the most part, chat makes intent quite clear. Gameplay, on the other hand, can be a trickier nut to crack. Most cases are pretty straightforward, but sometimes the system needs a little extra evidence before issuing a punishment.

The last thing Riot (or anyone) wants, is to ban someone for having a bad game. It sets a *very* bad precedent and is generally an awful scenario for all involved. The unfortunate consequence is that gameplay punishments can sometimes take a little longer to issue than anyone would like. 

In no way is it an instance of "we are punishing chat *instead* of gameplay". Both have their code of conduct and both are punished where appropriate. It is simply the timeframes that can differ on a case by case basis.
